segments.text: Good morning and welcome to Rising. We have a wonderful Monday morning show planned for you all today and it's so wonderful to see Batcha.
Angar Sargan. Hello Batcha.
Good morning, Robbie. How was your weekend?
Mine was very nice. Easter weekend, of course, didn't really actually do very much and was hoping for slightly warmer weather, but, you know, no complaining.
No complaints. How was yours?
Good, good. I have eaten a lot of matzas, so, you know, very excited for that to pass.
Alright, well, what are we talking about on the show today?
Well, we've got a big show coming up. Let's get right into it. The Department of Justice has opened an investigation after a trove of top secret defense documents spread on social media last week.
The documents, which first appeared on Discord about a month ago, detailed US intelligences extensive spy campaign, even against key allies, including Israel, South Korea and Ukraine.
The leaks also reveal the US military's extensive involvement in the day to day logistics of the war in Ukraine, leaving some members of the intelligence community rattled.

They say the relative freshness of the documents, some of them are around just a month old, about 40 days old, means that their leaking could have dire consequences on US and NATO operations in Ukraine.

According to the Times, quote, while President Biden has barred American troops from firing directly on Russian targets and blocked sending weapons that could reach deep into Russian territory, the documents make clear that a year into the invasion, the United States is heavily entangled

in almost everything else. So, Robbie, when I saw this news, I had sort of two main thoughts. My first was, you know, so what does the revelation of this extensive US spying operation deep in the Russian war machine and Russian government
and every level of basically the Russian intelligence operations? What does that mean for Evan Gershkovich's release?
I mean, you know, another humiliating, humiliating moment for Vladimir Putin. You know, does this make it more or less likely that we can get that Wall Street journalist home?
And I just fear that this is not going to be a moment that Putin will be open to negotiations.

Of course, this confirms what a lot of us already knew, which was that the US was providing intensive on the ground support, everything from the weapons themselves to coordinating locations within Russia that are going to be targets.
So the question, I think, becomes, you know, at what point does Russia view this as, you know, not a Cold War anymore, but a hot war between the US and Russia, which, of course, would be disastrous.
Right, really it's confirmation of a lot of things that we kind of, you know, that we suspected we know the US has a vast spying intelligence operation.
We know that we deploy that against not just hostile or ostensibly hostile nations like Russia, but we spy on Israel.
We spy on our friends too. And they do that to us. That's, you know, the way the modern intelligence world works.
But we are seeing, we see from this intelligence, yes, the level of detail and involvement US forces have in planning the Ukrainian war.
And, you know, some of these distinctions that are being drawn well, US troops are not specifically supposed to fire on Russian forces or advise on things that would affect the interior of Russia.
Like, are these distinctions Putin is going to make? Is he going to say, oh, yeah, yeah, well, the US hasn't declared war on Russia because they're only involved in the X, Y, and Z ways.

I don't know. If you look at this, you would, you know, conclude that we're basically, we're assisting, we're sort of directing the Ukrainian resistance, which, like, look, if you think that's appropriate, has Congress authorized that, has Congress, the body of our government
that is responsible for declaring war, did they authorize the president to carry out a war against Russia, defensive Ukraine? No, they didn't.

So I think it's, it can be confusing on that level. I also just kind of find it frankly interesting that, however, when we don't know exactly how these documents leaked in the first place, it could have been, you know, there are a number of countries we share a lot of intelligence with,
Canada, Australia, the UK, etc. It could have been one of those actually, kind of someone there with access to the information who shared it.

But it was on Discord for a month before anyone really noticed it, and it became a story that, wow, there's these intelligence documents out there, which I think just goes to show, it's just kind of wild how big the Internet is, that, you know, you could publish something on the Internet

in a public place, Discord, a public forum, a platform for discussion, and have it not actually, like, attract the attention of the government or the news media or the people who would say, hey, wait a minute, that's our secret stuff, we don't have anybody seeing that for a month.
That's kind of wild. Right, and it's important to note, I think that there are two competing versions of the documents. Pro-Russian sources have shared a version of the documents that has
the casualty count for Ukraine and for Russia, but the pro-Russian version appears to have been doctored to have swapped the numbers and make it look like the Ukrainian casualties are much higher.

So according to the documents being shared by the, you know, the news media in America, at least, the ones that appear to be the original documents show that Ukraine has had 17 soldiers killed in action compared to Russia's 42,000, I believe, was the number of people.
And the casualty numbers, of course, much higher casualty numbers for the Ukraine were somewhere like 170,000, and then for Russia, I think up to 225,000.

But in the pro-Russia sources, there's been a doctored version that flips that and has the Ukrainian casualties, you know, somewhere like, you know, 90,000 killed in action, which we don't believe to be the case.
So, you know, very interesting and very important to keep an eye on, you know, which of these are verified and which of these are not.

I will say another extremely interesting thing that has not gotten a lot of attention is that according to our spying on Israel, it appears that the Mossad was very heavily involved in encouraging and even, you know, instigating these mass protests that we saw against Benjamin Netanyahu's proposed judicial reform against the Supreme Court.
And make of that what you will, I assume there's going to now be a big conversation about the deep state in Israel as well because the Mossad historically has never interfered in domestic politics.

So that was a really interesting piece of the puzzle. And of course, the South Korean piece. I mean, South Korea is not going to be happy to know, and for the world to know that we were spying on such a close ally.

The deep state element of, yeah, the Israeli angle is fasting to see if that country, you know, increasingly has this, the same kind of thing we're seeing here in terms of intelligence officials, national security officials, kind of the government bureaucracy working against the

President, which is obviously what a lot of Trump supporters think and can present some credible evidence for, you know, was happening here in terms of, you know, the dissemination of the kind of Russian interference, Russian collusion narrative that took on social media that was really pushed by people in the FBI and national
intelligence gathering. A lot of that ended up being overstated, but so deeply affected the discourse in a negative way for the elected President, Donald Trump.

So to see that taking, I guess it's not really surprising. I wonder if every country has their version of a, you know, a permanent federal bureaucracy or whatever they call it, working sometimes with counter aims to the elected political officials. It's very, very interesting.

And I think troubling, you know, this is not a, this is not a pro-democracy trend, I would say, where a permanent bureaucracy of so-called experts works against the interests of the people actually voted into office by the citizens of the country does not seem like a democracy maximizing
the kind of media creatures bought into it, say exactly the opposite, that they're defending democracy by doing this kind of thing from the political appointees.
It doesn't make sense to me, but that's the way the narrative breaks on that one.
I will also say, I think it's very interesting who, who leaked these documents, right? I mean, in whose interest were these documents leaked?
I mean, you know, for people like us who are sort of skeptical of our level of involvement in this and want to see some sort of negotiated, you know, peace settlement, right?
Do these, does the leak of this document, the knowledge that we've, you know, acquired from them, does that make that more likely or less likely, right?
Which would help us kind of answer who would have done this, right?
Who saw this as in their interest? Because you could sort of see both sides of it, right?

You know, on the one hand, I think it's not great for Ukraine that, you know, everybody has all of this information about how deeply embedded the U.S. is it's going to force certain questions just like you mentioned, Robbie, about, has Congress authorized this.
Of course, unfortunately, they have not done enough to voice, if there is any opposition to it, there's not been much voicing of it that sort of humiliating walk back of the progressive letter.
You know, on the other hand, you know, you could, what possibly could the Russian response to this be other than to dig in further, right?
I mean, it's not a great moment right now.
I mean, so it's just interesting to think about how this complicates our involvement further and what happens next.
Yeah, does not seem like something that's going to get us closer to peace, unfortunately.
Yeah.

Well, Dominion Voting Systems lawsuit against Fox News is headed to a jury trial later this month following a decision at the end of March, which a judge ruled that the case should survive Fox's motion to dismiss.

Quote, the evidence developed in this civil proceeding, Judge Eric M. Davis wrote, demonstrates that it is crystal clear that none of the statements relating to Dominion about the 2020 election are true.
Now, the judge is correct about that and it's worth repeating. Claims that Joe Biden stole the election from Donald Trump via Dominion Voting Machines or any other conspiracy theory are false.
Biden was the legitimate winner of the 2020 election in the various claims put forward by Trump and his surrogates, Rudy Giuliani, Sidney Powell, etc., amounted to nothing.
There is no evidence of those claims and conservatives who took them seriously made a big mistake.
But in a society that values the free exchange of ideas, the proper response to bad speech is to counter it with good speech.
Dominion has every right to set the record straight and I understand, given all the lies spread by Trump and Powell and Giuliani, why the company would want to hold those people accountable.
But Dominion isn't just suing those people, it's also suing Fox News, the media company that interviewed Powell and Giuliani and others, inviting them on their programs to make their arguments.
Now, were some Fox hosts too credulous of the stolen election claims, especially Lou Dobbs, whose show was canceled and it was effectively fired?
Sure, would it have served them and their audience well to push back more aggressively?
Yes, although I would note that Tucker Carlson, after giving Sidney Powell every opportunity to present her case, totally eviscerated her evidence-free claims.
Let's watch.
We simply wanted to see the details, how could you not want to see them?
So we invited Sidney Powell on this show, we would have given her the whole hour, we would have given her the entire week actually, and listened quietly the whole time at wrapped attention.
That's a big story.
But she never sent us any evidence, despite a lot of requests, polite requests, not a page.
When we kept pressing, she got angry and told us to stop contacting her.
When we checked with others around the Trump campaign, people in positions of authority, they told us, Powell has never given them any evidence either.
In order to provide any today at the press conference, Powell did say that electronic voting is dangerous, and she's right, we're with her there.
But she never demonstrated that a single actual vote was moved illegitimately by software from one candidate to another, not one.
So why are we telling you this?
We're telling you this because it's true, and in the end that's all that matters, the truth.
It's our only hope, it's our best defense.
Now, viewers can make up their own minds about whether various hosts took too long to effectively respond to the election fraud claims, which again, I want to be crystal clear, are false claims.
What Rudy Giuliani said was false, what Sidney Powell said was false, what Donald Trump said was false.
But okay, maybe just sue those people because it's the work of journalists of news programs to cover the news, to interview people, even if they're saying really provocative and far out things.

You don't have to think the way Fox handled this subject was perfect, I certainly don't, but as someone who hosts a news show and interviews controversial people, people like Seymour Hirsch, who in the mainstream media is desperate to discredit, I'm worried about the precedent being established here,
that the platform, the news show, could be liable for defamation if it does not scrutinize its interview subjects in the exact manner that the targets of those interview subjects would ideally like.

If the news organization can be held liable for something a guest says, the guest isn't able to offer ironclad proof, how would that effect say this shows on reporting on Nord Stream, how would it affect coverage of COVID, a subject on which many people, even experts, passionately disagree about the implications of the available evidence?
How would it affect reporting on potential criminal misdewings by powerful people, like former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, Jeffrey Epstein?
Now Dominion is seeking $1.6 billion in its lawsuit, and let's say Fox can pay that, no problem.
But what signal does it send? What about the next lawsuit from someone who's mad about which guests a media company had on to discuss an issue?
Maybe the next target isn't as big and powerful as Fox, maybe it has a settlement without fighting it out in court.
We should be really worried about the potential chilling effect here.
The First Amendment offers a robust protection of free speech because we recognize that unfettered speech is vital for a democracy.
That includes the right to occasionally get things wrong and to explore ideas that don't pan out.
If the punishment for doing so is too great, people, journalists, we'll be too afraid to ask dangerous questions.
Will that make us better off? I don't think so. I don't think that's the country we want to live in.
So I've been wanting to weigh in on this for a while, not because I'm sympathetic at all to those ridiculous claims which are all false.
I'm not sympathetic to the people who made them, Sidney Powell, Rudy Giuliani, Donald Trump.
But I don't like this trend of trying to do indict an entire news organization and all the journalists that work there.

When I think having provocative discussions is important, the freedom to do that without risking massive financial loss is my mind important for American democracy, important for the principles of free speech.

And this case threatens to upset the balance that allows people to say provocative, questioning, important, challenging things, not necessarily even because the details here, but because this pushes the envelope so that the next time it's a little harder to speak and to dissent and to discuss.
That's what I'm worried will happen if there's a massive verdict in Dominion's favors, even though I totally agree that they were maligned by the individuals I've mentioned.
Yeah, I mean, if someone is hired by the president to do something, the fact that you don't like it doesn't make it not news, right?
And so what's effectively happening here is Fox is being punished for the fact that its viewers and perhaps some of its hosts wanted this to be true, right?
It's not for the fact that they spoke about it, it's that they didn't speak about it in a Condemni enough terms, right?
Because clearly it met the bar of being of interest to the public, right?
I mean, clearly this was something that was newsworthy that was happening in our nation.

I don't think the election was stolen.
But the president believed it, right?
And that made it newsworthy.

Like that's policing, you know, we don't believe in that in this society, right?

So I agree with you.

I don't always agree with them.
Often I don't agree with them.
And you're going to go out.

But if enforced would put us in a place where we could not, we could not run our show the way we want to.

Right.
And I'll just make one more quick point, which is that, you know, there is a debate among journalists when you're interviewing somebody deplorable, right?

Obviously you don't want to just give them free rein, right?

This is not right.

Those should not be legal questions.

That's very dangerous.
I'm not, I'm not willing to see that conversation to the law.
That's a journalistic and editorial conversation.
And that's what's really at stake here.
Honestly, it's free speech itself.
So we will continue to follow that lawsuit with great interest and concern and we'll have more rising right after this.

Last week, Chicago voters went to the polls to vote for their mayor in a runoff election that followed the ouster of Mayor Lori Lightfoot after just one term.
Lightfoot is the first Chicago mayor to lose reelection since 1983 and many saw her shocking loss as a referendum on rising crime.
Crime in Chicago was up by 20% over the last five years between 2021 and 2022.
Crime increased by 41% with theft, carjacking and homicides all up since 2019.
Lightfoot's miserable showing a third place, winning just 17% of the vote was viewed by many as a reflection of her inability to protect the residents of Chicago.
Especially its south and west side areas where gang violence is rampant.
Chicago's largely white north side on the other hand is as safe as it's been in a generation.
But the surprises were not over yet.

The man who won the runoff last week, Cook County Commissioner Brandon Johnson, ran to the left of Lightfoot in the initial election and initially supported the defund the police platform, though he later recanted.
He campaigned on raising taxes to support mental health resources, education and housing and had the endorsement of Chicago's teachers union.
Meanwhile, his competitor Paul Valis, also a Democrat though a moderate one, ran a tough on crime campaign that netted him the endorsement of the police union.
And it was he who took first place in the initial election, coming away with 33% of the vote, a massive 13 point lead over Johnson's 20%.
But Johnson managed to close that lead and then some finishing with a 2 point lead of 51% to Valis's 49%.
Though it's important to note that just 35% of the city's residents voted in the runoff.

Still, it is notable that faced with the choice between a defund the police candidate and one who had the backing of the Chicago police department, one third of the voters of a city experiencing the deadliest period in a quarter of a century went for the defund guy.
Not just that, Chicago is a deeply segregated city and the crime is heavily concentrated in poor black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
And irony of ironies, the area's hardest hit by violence voted overwhelmingly for Johnson as the Chicago Tribune reporter Jake Sheridan pointed out on Twitter.
Johnson seems to have gotten many of Lightfoot's voters, particularly her black voters.

A W.B.E.Z. analysis of the first round of voting found that the voters who initially picked both Valis and Johnson over Lightfoot lived in Chicago's safest neighborhoods and were more likely to be quote white college educated employed living in households earning more than $100,000 a year and sending their children to private schools.
Johnson kept many of those voters. He did well in the upscale areas like Hyde Park and Logan Square.
But voters in black neighborhoods seem to have played a decisive role in picking Chicago's next mayor.

And despite being disproportionately targeted as the victims of violent crime, they went for the guy least likely to target criminals by something like a 27% margin, polling from March found that 55% of black Chicagoans favored Johnson as opposed to just 28% who wanted Valis.
What gives?
For starters, 46% of registered black voters hadn't been contacted by either campaign.
Moreover, while 50% of black voters said reducing crime was the most important issue, 30% listed police reform as the second most important issue for them.
The winning message seems to be the one Eric Adams himself a former cop successfully ran on to beat two progressives in New York two years ago.
We have to have zero tolerance for violence, whether it's committed by criminals or by cops.
Here to help us unravel further, what's the matter with Chicago is Raphael Manuel, head of research for the policing and public safety initiative at the Manhattan Institute.
Thank you so much for joining us, Ralph. It's so great to have you.
So I think a lot of progressives are probably looking at this data and scoffing at people like me who say that, you know, progressive policies hurt the people they claim to represent most and last.
And laughing at me and saying, you see, this is what they actually want.
They want defund the police. They want, you know, to revert resources from cops and from policing towards, you know, mental health and housing, et cetera, et cetera. Are they right?
Not quite.
